g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Façade Provide a simple, unified interface to a sub-system (=...
g.text: FaçadeProvide a simple, unified interface to a sub-system (= set of classes)

g.title: Folded Corner.69
g.desc: The Façade pattern compliments the Single Responsibility prin...

g.text: The Façade pattern compliments the Single Responsibility principle by extracting object clustering, of a subsystem, from client code. This enhances the readability, reusability, testability and stability of the code base. All aspects are compared against an implementation where client clusters objects of a subsystem to realize a combined functionality. Readability, because the client is not ‘obscured’ by logic to cluster objects of a subsystem. The Façade ensures a single, simple interface so the client remains ‘focused’. Reusability, because the client has less dependencies and Façade logic is ‘distilled’. The client will have a smaller dependency model making it more reusable for other parts of the system. The object clustering of a subsystem (or execution sequences), the Façade, is centralized and separated from client logic. This will allow other clients to reuse the Façade without client logic being intertwined. Testability, because the dependency model of the client ‘shrinks’ resulting in a reduced problem window. A reduction in the problem window will result in more isolation during testing. Isolated testing will ensure bringing the code faster under test and finding bugs quicker/easier. This is not only applicable to the client, but to the Façade logic as well. Stability, because client and Façade logic are separated. Separation of concern decreases the chance of breaking code unrelated to the change. In contrast, intertwining façade and client logic increases the chance of breaking client logic when the façade requires change and vice versa.

g.title: Folded Corner.97
g.desc: The Façade pattern facilitates sub-system layering, by introd...

g.text: The Façade pattern facilitates sub-system layering, by introducing an entry point to another layer. Each sub-system communicates to a single, limited interface of the other sub-system. This makes change and re-use easier. Sub-systems or layers can we swapped with less impact, because there is low coupling.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: Clients need a simplified interface to a set of classes
g.text: Clients need a simplified interface to a set of classes

g.title: Rectangle.122
g.desc: Restrict clients from accessing details of a sub-system
g.text: Restrict clients from accessing details of a sub-system

g.title: Rectangle.124
g.desc: Possible violation and negative side of Single Responsibility
g.text: Possible violation and negative side of Single Responsibility

g.title: Folded Corner.138
g.desc: A well designed software sub-system will have multiple classe...

g.text: A well designed software sub-system will have multiple classes all serving a single responsibility. This results in multiple interfaces all around the sub-system. This can be ‘overwhelming’ and complex for clients whom dependent on the sub-system, because clients are required to compose the correct execution sequences of multiple objects them-self. The Façade pattern can help with unifying object interfaces as a goal to provide a simplified interface. I.e.: Façade facilitates an abstraction, by grouping objects of a sub-system, to provide a simplified interface to the client.

g.title: Folded Corner.189
g.desc: The Façade pattern provides a limited, simplified interface t...

g.text: The Façade pattern provides a limited, simplified interface to the client. The simplified interface results in clients being restricted in their interaction with the sub-system. This restriction prevents clients from interacting with the system in an ‘unforeseen’ way that might result in failure or damage to a system. The larger the interface of a system the harder it will become to oversee all possible error scenario’s. Restriction provides more control over execution.

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Façade, in the Façade design pattern, unifies sub-system ...

g.text: The Façade, in the Façade design pattern, unifies sub-system classes. This unification can be identified as a ‘god’ like object. However, in the non-strict sense, the Façade has one responsibility, namely to cluster and delegate object calls to simplify interfacing to a subsystem. However, we have to carefully monitor if the Façade will not become the place to make quick and easy fixes by adding responsibilities there, because it is after all an unified ‘place’ where a lot of objects come together. A ‘God’ object is the inverse of SRP. It will be hard to extend, bring it under test and analyze problems. On top of that, the Façade introduces an additional form of indirection between client and classes of a subsystem. This has negative affect on the navigability and debuggability of the code.

g.title: Folded Corner.215
g.desc: Façade pattern compliments Interface Segregation by decouplin...

g.text: Façade pattern compliments Interface Segregation by decoupling subsystem details from the client. This enhances the stability and maintainability of the code. All aspects are compared against an implementation where client dependents on details of a subsystem. That is, multiple different classes that make up the subsystem. Stability, because the details of a subsystem can evolve independent from the client. As a result, the chance of breaking client production and test code will be reduced. In contrast, ‘allowing’ the client to dependent on the individual classes, that make up the subsystem, will increase the chance of breaking client code. Using the Façade, the dependency towards the subsystem can be reduced to a single entry point. This allows the subsystem to change more freely. The Façade pattern also enhance the stability of the code via restriction. The simplified interface towards a subsystem ensures restricted interaction with the subsystem. This allows to more clearly oversee and control the interactions with the subsystem. As a consequence, ‘unforeseen’ execution sequences are minimized, resulting in fewer bugs. Maintainability, because clients do not require recompilation in case the internals of a subsystem change. In contrast, if clients dependent directly on the individual classes of a subsystem, it will result in client recompilation when one of the subsystem classes changes. The Façade might reduce recompilation of our code base.
